ADDRESS: 406 Lonsdale Street, Melbourne, C.l.
MAIN ACTIVITY: Solicitors.
DATE OF TRANSFER: March 1962.
GENERAL NOTE: Sands & McDougall's (formerly Sands & Kenny's) Melbourne Directories give the following information:
1857: Robert E. Lewis, solicitor, listed at 192 Napier-st., Collingwood. Edw. Ladner, storekeeper, at same address.
1858: Address 50 Napier-st, with Letchford & Raper, aerated water manufacturers and wine and spirit merchants.
1859: Address 144 Napier-st., between Condell and Moor Sts. Described as notary public.
1860: Above address and of Brodribb, Crisp & Lewis, solicitors, 51 Little Collins-st., west. Note: K.E. Brodribb listed in 1855 Directory. In 1857 (1856 missing) the firm is Brodribb & Crisp.
1866: Private address listed as Victoria Pde., Fitzroy.
1867: Firm becomes Crisp & Lewis, 51 Chancery Lane (= Lit. Collins St.).
1868: Private address Barry-st., Carlton.
1870: Firm becomes Crisp, Lewis & Wilkes. (John Wilkes is new partner).
1871: R.E. Lewis noted as absent in England.
1874: Private address is Malvern-lodge, Malvern.
1875: Firm again becomes Crisp & Lewis.
1877 Firm becomes Crisp, Lewis & Hedderwick at 41 & 43 Queen St. Henry Hedderwick new partner.
1881: Missing.
1882: Firm at 51 & 53 Lit. Collins-st., west.
1884: Name of firm the same, but W.J. Fookes taken into partnership.
1886: Private residence at Dickens-st., St. Kilda.
1889: Firm at 414 Lit. Collins-st.
1890: Thos. Crisp no longer in partnership. Lewis' private residence St. James' Park, Shakespeare Grove, Hawthorn.
1901: Firm becomes Lewis, Hedderwick & Fookes, with R.E. Lewis jnr. in partnership.
1907: Firm becomes R.E. Lewis & Son, still at 414 Lit. Collins Street.
1928 Firm becomes Lewis, R.E. & Beacham Kiddle.
1937: Firm becomes R.E. Lewis.
1938: Firm becomes R.E. Lewis & Son.
1942: Change of address to 318 Collins St.
1943: Change to 379 Collins St.
1957: Firm becomes R.E. Lewis, Orr & Gibson. Partners are Radcliffe Lewis, Wm. G. Orr and J.S. Gibson.
1959: Address changes to 406 Lonsdale St. in March.
LIST OF RECORDS

Note: The records are listed in alphabetical order according to the name of the firm's client. Whenever it has survived, the filing number of the firm is recorded after the quantity description of the document. It seems probable that there are several series of these filing numbers, but it was not possible to differentiate between them. A comprehensive index of all parties to the documents and places mentioned therein will be found at the end of the list of records.

ROBERTSON FAMILY.
Note: These papers were found in a large tin trunk marked "James G.
Robertson, Mt. Mitchell". They have been grouped under several
headings for the purposes of this list. The groups are:-
GROUP 1
Deeds re Land Transactions.
GROUP 2
Family Agreements.
GROUP 3
Wills and Estates.
GROUP 4
Scrip and sundries.
GROUP 5
Plans, maps, etc.
Thomas Robertson, with his wife, three sons, James, John, and Thomas, and
two daughters Jane (later Skene) and Margaret (later Philip), arrived in
Melbourne early in 1840 from Glenmuick, Aberdeenshire, Scotland. The
family settled at Mt. Mitchell in 1846, and worked as a partnership
Robertson & Sons until 1872. Thomas senior died later the same year, and
the three sons divided the property acquired by the family. Thomas
received his share in money, James took Mt. Mitchell, Pleasant Banks,
Heath Springs East, Lockhart, and Moray West properties while John
became the proprietor of Yarram Yarram including the Wannon run, and
Victoria Valley including the Moora Moora and Gazette runs.
It is chiefly with James and his descendants that the bulk of the papers
is concerned. He married Margaret Gordon, and there were four sons and
three daughters of the marriage - Thomas, James Gordon, John Gordon,
Francis Robert Gordon, Annie (who remained unmarried), Christina Gordon
(later Morrison), and Margaret Gordon (later Buchanan).
James Gordon Robertson married Anne Bath Farrer; there was one son,
James Rowland, who later held the Skene property.
Thomas and his wife Grace had at least one son, John Seymour. John
Gordon Robertson died unmarried, and Margaret Gordon Buchanan died
without issue.
Francis had three sons and one daughter - James Ochiltree, Francis
Ochiltree, Gordon Ochiltree and Jean Ochiltree (later Beatson). Francis
lived on Mortat, at Goroke.
Christina Gordon Morrison's children were James Robert, John Gordon and
Margaret Gordon.
